1. Executive Summary
GreenTech Energy Holdings plc ('the Company') is a diversified energy company headquartered in
London, United Kingdom, operating across renewable energy generation, energy storage solutions,
and grid infrastructure services. The Company operates in 14 countries across Europe, North
America, and the Asia-Pacific region, employing approximately 8,200 people.
This report has been prepared in accordance with IFRS S1 (General Requirements for Disclosure of
Sustainability-related Financial Information) and IFRS S2 (Climate-related Disclosures) as issued by
the International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) in June 2023. The reporting boundary
covers all entities over which GreenTech exercises operational control.
During the 2024 financial year, the Company made significant progress in its sustainability
transformation. Total renewable energy generation capacity increased by 23% to 4.8 GW, while
total Scope 1 and 2 emissions decreased by 18% year-on-year. The Company invested GBP 620
million in clean energy projects and secured GBP 1.2 billion in green bond financing to support its
net-zero transition pathway.

2. Governance
IFRS S1 Pillar: Governance
2.1 Board Oversight
The Board of Directors maintains ultimate oversight of sustainability-related risks and opportunities.
The Board comprises 12 members, of whom 4 have specific expertise in climate science,
environmental policy, or sustainable finance. The Board's Sustainability Committee, chaired by Dr.
Sarah Chen (former IPCC lead author), meets quarterly to review climate risk assessments,
approve sustainability targets, and monitor progress against the Company's Net Zero Roadmap
2040.
In FY2024, the Sustainability Committee held 6 meetings (up from 4 in FY2023) and reviewed 14
papers covering topics including updated Scope 3 emissions methodology, physical risk exposure of
coastal assets, the Company's just transition framework, and proposed science-based targets
aligned with the SBTi 1.5 degrees C pathway. The Committee's recommendations were adopted by

2.2 Management Accountability
The Chief Sustainability Officer (CSO), Maria Torres, reports directly to the CEO and is a member of
the Executive Leadership Team (ELT). The CSO is responsible for integrating sustainability
considerations into strategic planning, capital allocation, and operational decision-making.
Sustainability KPIs are embedded in the annual performance objectives of all ELT members, with
20% of short-term incentive compensation linked to climate and sustainability metrics.
The Sustainability Working Group, comprising 28 members from operations, finance, legal, risk, and
investor relations, meets monthly to coordinate implementation of the sustainability strategy.
Regional sustainability leads in each of the Company's 14 operating countries report to the CSO
through a matrix structure.

3. Strategy
IFRS S1 Pillar: Strategy
3.1 Sustainability-Related Risks and Opportunities
The Company has identified material sustainability-related risks and opportunities that could
reasonably be expected to affect its cash flows, access to finance, or cost of capital over the short
term (0-2 years), medium term (2-10 years), and long term (10-30 years). The most significant risks
include physical climate impacts on coastal and water-dependent assets, regulatory transition risks
from evolving carbon pricing mechanisms, and technology disruption risks in the rapidly evolving
energy storage market.
Key opportunities include accelerating demand for renewable energy driven by government net-zero
commitments, the growing green bond and sustainable finance market, carbon credit generation
from nature-based solutions, and emerging revenue streams from green hydrogen production. The
Company estimates that climate-related opportunities could contribute an additional GBP 800
million to annual revenue by 2030 under a 1.5 degrees C scenario.
3.2 Business Model Impact
Climate change affects GreenTech's business model across the entire value chain. On the supply
side, increased frequency of extreme weather events has disrupted equipment supply chains
(estimated impact: GBP 45 million in FY2024). On the demand side, growing policy support for
decarbonization has driven a 34% increase in power purchase agreement (PPA) volumes. The
Company's transition from fossil fuel generation (now 12% of capacity, down from 28% in 2020) to
100% renewables by 2035 requires estimated capital expenditure of GBP 4.2 billion over the period
2025-2035.

4. Risk Management
IFRS S1 Pillar: Risk Management
4.1 Risk Identification Process
GreenTech employs a comprehensive enterprise risk management (ERM) framework that integrates
climate and sustainability risks into the broader risk taxonomy. Climate-related risks are identified
through a combination of top-down scenario analysis, bottom-up asset-level vulnerability
assessments, and horizon scanning of regulatory and technological developments. The Company
engages external climate scientists and risk consultants (including Willis Towers Watson and Marsh
McLennan) to supplement internal capabilities.
All identified risks are assessed on a 5-point scale for both likelihood and impact (financial,
operational, reputational, and regulatory dimensions). Risks scoring 4 or above on either dimension
are escalated to the Board Sustainability Committee. In FY2024, 23 climate-related risks were
identified, of which 7 were classified as 'High' or 'Critical'.

6. Climate-Related Disclosures
IFRS S2: Climate-Related Disclosures
This section provides climate-specific disclosures in accordance with IFRS S2. The Company
recognizes climate change as the most significant sustainability-related risk to its business model
and has embedded climate considerations into every aspect of its strategy, operations, and
governance.
6.1 Climate-Related Risks
The Company faces both physical and transition climate risks. Physical risks include acute risks
such as increased frequency and severity of storms, floods, and wildfires affecting generation
assets and grid infrastructure, as well as chronic risks including rising sea levels threatening coastal
installations, changing precipitation patterns affecting hydroelectric output, and increasing
temperatures reducing the efficiency of solar panels and thermal cooling systems.
Transition risks encompass policy and legal risks from evolving carbon pricing and emissions
regulations, technology risks from rapid evolution in battery storage and green hydrogen, market
risks from shifting energy demand patterns and commodity price volatility, and reputational risks
associated with the pace and credibility of the Company's decarbonization commitments.

7.2 Adaptation Measures
The Company has implemented and planned the following adaptation measures: (1) Elevation of
critical electrical infrastructure at coastal sites by 1.5 meters above current 100-year flood levels at a
cost of GBP 45 million; (2) Installation of advanced wildfire detection and suppression systems at all
California and Australian solar installations (GBP 8 million); (3) Diversification of water sources for
thermal cooling, including recycled water agreements (GBP 12 million investment); (4) Enhanced
structural resilience standards for offshore wind turbines exceeding IEC 61400 requirements by
15%, adding GBP 2.3 million per installation.

8. Transition Risk Assessment
8.1 Policy and Regulatory Risks
The Company operates in multiple jurisdictions with evolving carbon pricing and emissions
regulations. In FY2024, carbon costs under the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) and UK
Emissions Trading Scheme (UK ETS) totaled GBP 38 million, up from GBP 24 million in FY2023.
Under the Company's central scenario, carbon prices are projected to reach EUR 120/tCO2e by
2030 and EUR 180/tCO2e by 2040, resulting in estimated cumulative exposure of GBP 420 million
over 2025-2035 if current emission levels were maintained. The Company's decarbonization
pathway reduces this exposure to an estimated GBP 185 million.
8.2 Technology Risks
Rapid technological change in the energy sector presents both risks and opportunities. The
Company's current battery storage technology (lithium-ion NMC) faces potential displacement from
emerging solid-state batteries, sodium-ion technologies, and iron-air systems. To mitigate this risk,
GreenTech maintains technology partnerships with 6 battery manufacturers and invests GBP 35
million annually in R&D; through its GreenTech Innovation Lab. The Company has also secured
technology licensing agreements for two next-generation storage technologies.
8.3 Market and Reputational Risks
Shifting energy demand patterns driven by electrification of transport and heating create both upside
and downside risks. The Company's scenario analysis indicates that total electricity demand in its
markets could increase by 40-65% by 2040. Reputational risk is managed through transparent
reporting, third-party verification of emissions data, and active stakeholder engagement. The
Company's sustainability claims are subject to annual limited assurance by

10.3 Strategic Resilience
The scenario analysis demonstrates that GreenTech's strategy is most resilient under the Net Zero
2050 scenario, with a cumulative net positive financial impact of GBP 2,340 million through 2040.
Under the Current Policies scenario, the Company faces net negative impact of GBP 625 million
driven primarily by increased physical damage costs and stranded assets. The Delayed Transition
scenario results in moderate net positive impact but with higher carbon cost volatility post-2030. The
Board has concluded that the Company's current Net Zero 2040 strategy provides robust resilience
across all scenarios and has authorized an acceleration of the renewable transition timeline.

12. Forward-Looking Statements and Net Zero
Pathway
GreenTech is committed to achieving net-zero greenhouse gas emissions across Scopes 1, 2, and
3 by 2040, ten years ahead of the Paris Agreement timeline. The Company's decarbonization
pathway includes the following milestones: complete phase-out of fossil fuel generation by 2032;
100% renewable electricity procurement by 2028; 50% reduction in Scope 3 emissions by 2035;
deployment of 2 GW of green hydrogen electrolysis capacity by 2035; and investment of GBP 4.2
billion in clean energy infrastructure over 2025-2035.
The Company acknowledges that achieving these targets depends on several external factors
including government policy support, technology cost reductions, supply chain capacity, and the
pace of grid modernization. The Company will report annually on progress against these targets and
will update its pathway as new information becomes available. All forward-looking statements in this
report are based on current expectations and are subject to material risks and uncertainties.

Appendix A: Methodology
Greenhouse gas emissions have been calculated in accordance with the GHG Protocol Corporate
Standard (revised 2015) and the GHG Protocol Corporate Value Chain Standard. Scope 1
emissions include direct combustion of natural gas at thermal generation facilities and fugitive
emissions from SF6 in electrical switchgear. Scope 2 emissions are reported on both a
market-based and location-based methodology. Market-based figures reflect the purchase of
Renewable Energy Guarantees of Origin (REGOs) and contractual instruments. Scope 3 emissions
cover 8 of the 15 GHG Protocol categories determined to be material through a screening exercise.
Physical risk assessments used CMIP6 climate projections (SSP1-2.6, SSP2-4.5, SSP5-8.5)
downscaled to 5km resolution using statistical downscaling methods. Asset-level vulnerability was
assessed using the UNEP-FI Physical Risk Assessment Methodology. Financial impacts were
estimated using internal damage functions calibrated against historical loss data.
Scenario analysis was conducted using the NGFS Climate Scenarios (Phase IV, released
November 2023) with company-specific financial modeling. Carbon price trajectories, energy
demand projections, and technology cost curves were sourced from the IEA World Energy Outlook
2024 and IRENA Renewable Power Generation Costs 2024.
